issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw: OK, thanks for info. In our case binary data \(OSGAR logfile\) would be more valuable because we could replay the run 1:1 locally \(to see what was going on\). It is like ROS bag, but much smaller. Also image for artifact detection and when collision occurred could give us some hints \(stones, boards, etc.\).
content.html: OK, thanks for info. In our case binary data (OSGAR logfile) would be more valuable because we could replay the run 1:1 locally (to see what was going on). It is like ROS bag, but much smaller. Also image for artifact detection and when collision occurred could give us some hints (stones, boards, etc.).

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw: Unfortunately, we don't have a mechanism establish to pull log files off of a robot (solution) container. We can only pull data off the bridge, which is running the ros master and can capture console output.
content.html: Unfortunately, we don't have a mechanism establish to pull log files off of a robot (solution) container. We can only pull data off the bridge, which is running the ros master and can capture console output.

Is there a chance to log stdout/stderr of solution docker? \(maybe it is already available I have not notice it\). In my last attempt \(“ver0”\) the docker python code probably ended with some failure \(I guess\), so is it possible to modify my docker that I could see its output?

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw: [ROS Console](http://wiki.ros.org/roscpp/Overview/Logging)  messages  are captured in the ROS log files. So, statements like `ROS_DEBUG("My robot is moving");` should appear in the ROS logs downloaded from the portal.
content.html: ROS Console messages are captured in the ROS log files. So, statements like ROS_DEBUG("My robot is moving"); should appear in the ROS logs downloaded from the portal.

content.raw:
I would reopen this issue as robots behaves probably differently on AWS then locally. I can catch some indication via "rosout.log" (thanks for that) but I would still need to save some binary debug info (say images used for artifact recognition).

Is for example communication between robots logged? If yes only successful or all? For example can the robot return to Base Station and "dump" some binary block, which I could later find in `state.tlog` for example?

Thanks for any hint.

p.s. the size binary block could be 200kB (JPEG image), 10MB (stripped log file), 200MB (logfile with QVGA video).

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw:
Hi Arthur,

I am not sure what others use for debugging, but for us it is primarily OSGAR binary log file. So ideally we could get it as result of simulation. For Tunnel Circuit we hacked it to dump it into `rosout.log` … which is a bit crazy, but it sometimes worked. That is the source where is see strange data from IMU or accelerometers. There are also images related to detected artifacts …

So back to your question - by `final dump` I mean copy of this binary logfile. As far as I know docker can mount external disk … that could be one way. Another option is what Nate mentioned, so that we could call some Ignition function to upload the data … that is in the case when everything works fine. But mostly it does not, so very valuable are the data when robot end up somewhere up-side-down … 

Is this explanation better?

thanks

m.

‌
content.html:
Hi Arthur,

I am not sure what others use for debugging, but for us it is primarily OSGAR binary log file. So ideally we could get it as result of simulation. For Tunnel Circuit we hacked it to dump it into rosout.log … which is a bit crazy, but it sometimes worked. That is the source where is see strange data from IMU or accelerometers. There are also images related to detected artifacts …

So back to your question - by final dump I mean copy of this binary logfile. As far as I know docker can mount external disk … that could be one way. Another option is what Nate mentioned, so that we could call some Ignition function to upload the data … that is in the case when everything works fine. But mostly it does not, so very valuable are the data when robot end up somewhere up-side-down …

Is this explanation better?

thanks

m.

‌

We can wait to merge all pull requests until nightly docker images are complete, but that will delay access to features.

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw:
@{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0} the `unittest6` works! :slight_smile: … so it seems that the topic can be named as you wish, but the type has to be `std_msgs::String` i.e.  

```
this->robotDataPub = this->n.advertise<std_msgs::String>("/robot_data", 1);
```

‌
content.html:
@Nate Koenig the unittest6 works! … so it seems that the topic can be named as you wish, but the type has to be std_msgs::String i.e. 

this->robotDataPub = this->n.advertise<std_msgs::String>("/robot_data", 1);

‌

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw:
Yes, we are using this feature \(be aware of overflow when you loose the first data\). 

[https://github.com/robotika/osgar/blob/master/subt/docker/robotika/ros\_proxy\_node.cc#L295-L296](https://github.com/robotika/osgar/blob/master/subt/docker/robotika/ros_proxy_node.cc#L295-L296)

‌

```
this->robotDataPub = this->n.advertise<std_msgs::String>("/robot_data", 1);
```

‌
content.html:
Yes, we are using this feature (be aware of overflow when you loose the first data).

https://github.com/robotika/osgar/blob/master/subt/docker/robotika/ros_proxy_node.cc#L295-L296

‌

this->robotDataPub = this->n.advertise<std_msgs::String>("/robot_data", 1);

‌

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw: Yes, it is named only `/robot_data` and it is only available “locally” within the particular robot. Also you find the ROS bag in log of your particular robot.
content.html: Yes, it is named only /robot_data and it is only available “locally” within the particular robot. Also you find the ROS bag in log of your particular robot.

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw: Thank you!
content.html: Thank you!

issue.title: [Urban Feature] Access to simulation robot logfile?

content.raw:
@{5b5b1c941394ae6a72c021df} each vehicle runs on a separate instance and their `/robot_data*` topics do not overlap.

When testing, I use a relay with message dropping to keep bags small when testing to record maps i.e.:
`<node pkg="topic_tools" type="drop" name="$(anon relay_map)" args="/$(arg name)/map 9 10 /robot_data/$(arg name)/map" respawn="true"    />`
that drops 9/10 messages from `/$(arg name)/map` when relaying to `/robot_data/$(arg name)/map` for recording.

You can then use a bag combining tool to stitch all of the bags back together and strip the `/robot_data*` prefix if you're interested in having a singular bag per experiment.
content.html:
@Hector Escobar each vehicle runs on a separate instance and their /robot_data* topics do not overlap.

When testing, I use a relay with message dropping to keep bags small when testing to record maps i.e.: <node pkg="topic_tools" type="drop" name="$(anon relay_map)" args="/$(arg name)/map 9 10 /robot_data/$(arg name)/map" respawn="true" /> that drops 9/10 messages from /$(arg name)/map when relaying to /robot_data/$(arg name)/map for recording.

You can then use a bag combining tool to stitch all of the bags back together and strip the /robot_data* prefix if you're interested in having a singular bag per experiment.
